clean_story:
"Pedestrian pathways. Concrete or stone underfoot. "

The word sidewalk comes from "side" and "walk"—a designated space for people to move alongside roads, separate from vehicles.

Most see sidewalks as simple slabs, but their design balances durability, drainage, and accessibility.

A standard sidewalk is 4–6 feet wide, built with 4-inch-thick concrete or interlocking pavers.

Curb cuts—sloped edges at intersections—were mandated in the U. S. after the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act, ensuring wheelchair access.

In Tokyo, "tactile paving" (raised bumps or bars) guides visually impaired pedestrians—dots signal stops, lines indicate safe paths.

Sidewalks also manage rainwater: slight slopes (1–2% grade) direct flow to storm drains, preventing puddles.

Three related subjects are urban heat islands, pedestrian psychology, and permeable pavement designs.
